captions.text:
MATT FARAH: Now we know that the
Scion FRS and Subaru BRZ

are fun to drive because you
can drive then at 10 tenths
basically all the time.

Earlier this season, we learned
that if you put a

bolt-on turbo kit, making it an
extra 100 horsepower, that

they don't lose their
overall flavor.

But what happens when you take
a Subaru BRZ and double the

horsepower and triple
the torque output?

That means a fully built engine
from the ground up and

everything that goes
along with it.

That's why we borrowed
Crawford's Subaru BRZ for the

day, which makes 430 horsepower
and 500 pounds of
torque on pumped gas.
I just like saying that.
I love Subarus.
Well, not all Subarus.
The new Outback is huge.

The new STI is too expensive
and not very pretty.

And the new Tribeca inexplicably
shares a grill
with a Chrysler 200.

No, I love older Subarus, the
early 2000 WRX 22 B's, the

super sleeper fourth gen Legacy
GT Wagon, even the

ultra-light Impreza L, which
makes for a perfect
project Rally car.

But if you want to talk new
Subarus, this is it.
It's the BRZ.

It's the first rear-drive
Subaru in 40 years.

And as both the reviews
and the sales
have shown, it's fantastic.

The balance, the controls, the
seats, the style, and the

price are all right where they
need to be so you can enjoy

your car stock, but also
use it as a platform
for a tuning project.

But where to start with
your tuning project?
How about the engine.

It's not often that
Subaru releases a
completely new box or engine.

It's been three years since the
last one, and it was 21
years before that.

And the all-new FA 20 motor
powering the Subaru BRZ is an
engine worth waiting for.

Now, before you start running
to the comments section and

writing in all caps about how
slow the 86 Twins are,

remember, this is "TUNED," not
"Top Gear." On "TUNED," it's

not important how much
power an engine
makes from the factory.

It's all about how
much it can make.

And according to Quirt
Crawford, the FA20 is
the best boxer yet.
QUIRT CRAWFORD: You know what?
I'm damn good at it.
I'm damn good at making power.

I'm Really good at
spending money.

I would say the car probably
had about 800 miles on it

before the engine
came out of it.
And then out it came.

And the only reason it had
that many miles on it is

because I was waiting for the
pistons and rods to show up.

Otherwise, it would've
been out sooner.

I basically increased the valve
springs a little bit on

it to compensate for the extra
boost to the motor.

Other than that, that was where
we started at with the

motor, just to do the R&D and
see what it liked, and then

put it in the car and started
breaking parts.

The first issue we
had was clutch.

The first clutch we put in the
car would only hold about--

475 pounds of torque
was about it.

Next thing we broke was the CV
joint in the back of the car.
That didn't take long either.

But other than that, we haven't
really been breaking
too many parts.
It's been pretty reliable.

The motor has been
very reliable.

This particular engine is much
stronger than the EJ motor.
It really likes to make power.

The same turbo we've put on this
engine, on an STI, we can
make like 360 horsepower.
On this motor, it made 430.
Same turbo, smaller motor.

The FA motor really likes
making power.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

MATT FARAH: That was an obscene
speed, straight

uphill, up a very steep
hill at that.

I mean, this is now--
this is not an
entry-level sports car anymore.
This thing is a rocket ship.
And it is [BLEEP]
awesome.

What happens when you double the
horsepower and triple the

torque via a fully built engine,
not even huge turbo,

and a lot of tuning know-how,
and you end up with a car that

has a better power-to-weight
ratio than a 911 Turbo?
997 Turbo.

Anyone who has seen Gymkhana
1, which is everyone,

basically, knows what
Crawford is.

They built Ken Block's famous
first Gymkhana Subaru.

These guys have been doing
Subaru engines and nothing but

Subaru engines for a
really long time.

And yes, we have driven a
Turbo FRS on the show.

That was a bolt-on kit that
went on a stock motor.
This is very, very different.

On pump gas, this car makes
430 horsepower and
500 pounds of torque.

You want to run E85, which is
on the fly with the maps
they've got in here.

It makes an extra 50
on top of that.

You're talking almost 500
horsepower in a rear-wheel

drive car that weighs
2,700 pounds.

I mean, that's better than Z06
Corvettes That's better than a
Porsche Turbo.

That is ridiculous from
2 liters in a
rear-wheel drive Subaru.

QUIRT CRAWFORD: Basically,
doubling the horsepower of the

engine and tripling the torque
takes it from a vehicle that
you drive it at--

you know, with a couple hundred
horsepower, you drive
it at 110% all the time.

With this setup, I drive
the car at 20%, maybe.

Very rarely do I squeeze
the throttle because it
just wants to go.

And I guess I could say it's an
accident waiting to happen,

or a ticket it waiting
to happen as well.

So I drive it pretty gingerly
most of the time.

MATT FARAH: We haven't driven
a car in a long time that

sounds like "Fast and the
Furious." When you think tuner

cars, this is what
you think of--

4 cylinder, bunch of boost, that
sound, that sound, but
it's great.

Steering feel still awesome,
lightweight still awesome, you

can shred the hell out of the
rear tires through the first
three gears.

And it's still got plenty of
that character that I love
about these cars.

You just have to be a little bit
more careful now because

when that boost comes on, you
get peak boost at 3,500 RPMs.

So sort of like an old 911,
you've got to know when that

boost is coming on, know where
your foot is, know where the

car's pointed when
boost happens.

QUIRT CRAWFORD: I would say the
car probably have close to

200 dynapoles on it, and then
lots of track time, and lots
and lots of street time.

I usually change the map in
it two, three times a day.
It's my daily driver.

So I drive it home,
change the map.

Drive it to work,
change the map.

Drive it to lunch,
change the map.

Put it on the dyno, change
the map a bunch of times.

MATT FARAH: It really does have
the best steering feel of

any car you can buy
under $60,000.
It's like this and a Cayman.

That's the steering
feel champions.
It's a got a great shifter.

Ah! you're going to have to
start behaving on me, motor.

I'm not sure why, because it
seems like they've done a lot

of research on this car, but
it seems to be breaking up

above 4,000 RPM in every
gear but first.
There's third gear.

Ah, it worked that
time [CHUCKLES].

OK, maybe I just had to call
it out on misbehaving, and
it's like, oh, yeah, oh that.
Oh, you wanted me to work.
Oh, OK.
Yeah, it works good now.
Oh, there we go.
Holy [BLEEP].

OK, when it works right, good
God, is that thing fast, man.

It's crazy what you can do with
a 2-liter engine, some
boost, and rear-wheel drive.

And that Boxer engine layout,
it's all about the torque.

Tom has to leave for the airport
in two hours, and I'm
in the Crawford BRZ.

And you'll notice I'm not on
a canyon road right now.

I'm in a strip mall
parking lot.
Why?

Because even though we only have
3 and 1/2 hours to shoot

this, Tom had to stop
for a sandwich.

And when I mean had to, I mean,
he literally refuses to

work unless he eats a sandwich
first, even though he's the

reason that we only have three
hours to make this film.

You're getting four
sandwiches?

TOM: I'm going to get
five sandwiches.
You want something, right?
MATT FARAH: Sure.

I mean, if you're getting
five, I mean--
[CHUCKLES].

title: The 450 HP Crawford Performance Turbo BRZ - /TUNED

they are the first thing that needs replaced. While you are in there you 
should also put  some lower compression turbo pistons. That is all you will 
need to upgrade to make 700+HP.

The exhaust manifold is equal length on our turbo BRZ, but the length of 
the tubes has almost nothing to do with the sound of the motor. The firing 
order is what changes the sound coming from the engine the most.

comments.text:
+Meli Hampton There is no difference between the GT86/FRZ/BRZ except front 
bumper, front fender, interior trim levels and options. Also the GT86/FRS 
suspension setup is more drift oriented and a bit stiffer in the back. The 
BRZ is more for grip and a little stiffer ride because it has stiffer front 
suspension. The BRZ is more for the track :D

comments.text:
+Meli Hampton
Exactly!! ; ) which I would never be caught driving a hyunDie or any Korean 
car for that matter.

Ohhhh... Toyota starlet!!!  Is it the kp61?
Those things look bad ass if done right.

Every car I own has it function:
Solara main car/ daily driver: cost $3000
Integra first car I owned/bought great on gas: cost $1500
SC Previa, my parents use to own one, at first growing up I hate it, but 
later I just fell in love with it. Picked one up for $2500. Low miles.
Most reliable car I have ever seen 400,000 + miles on my parents one.
240sx was sort of a gift from my uncle, had a blown engine. I fixed it and 
its fun to drive. Being RWD.
240z is the car of my dreams, my project car, my unicorn, my heart of gold. 
Enough said. Cost $3000.




Plus I can't pick up chicks....lol............so why not.

It has nothing to do with how similar they are it has to do with car 
enthusiast and being a gear head. I own a 00' Solara, 93' 240sx, 97'

will be the first time I spend more than 10 stacks on a car at one time and 
I don't want it to be label as a chick car. The gt86 is the next gen of the 
legendary Toyota A86….a tribute to it. Call me sexist but I don't want it 
to be a chick thing. That’s why I want the Toyota version. 

Man just watch “Initial D”.

was a joint project developed together by both Toyota and Subaru.

Basically, Subaru makes the mechanics whereas Toyota makes the body work 
and such.

comments.author: Jerry Velasco

comments.text:
The Toyota 86/Subaru BRZ was a joint project co-developed by Toyota and 
Subaru. Basically, Subaru was to be responsible for the engine and 
powertrain, while Toyota developed the chassis, bodywork, and pretty much 
everything else.
comments.author: ZeroStriker426

power, same torque, same engine, same everything.

comments.text: How would this fare vs a stock 2015 STI? On and off track?﻿
comments.author: Axel Valle

comments.text:
The BRZ is a good bit lighter and has more power... but the STI is all 
wheel drive. From a dead stop the STI would pull away but the BRZ would run 
it down. On a small tight track the STI would have a slight advantage but 
on a bigger track the the BRZ would again prevail.

compression.

comments.author: xKAMRONx

comments.text:
Our comparison is based on crank horse power not wheel horse power. We can 
push 370/380 horse power out of the EJ25 with the OEM turbo and we got 430 
horse power from the FA20 with the same OEM turbo. That said, all the shops 
that have pushed both platforms know that the new FA motor is a more 
efficient motor.

Motul fluids
Crawford low compression turbo FA engine
Crawford twin scroll turbo kit

Crawford spec Billet rods
Crawford spec head studs
Exedy Clutch
Crawford Air Oil Separator
Crawford high pressure coolant tank
Larger radiator
K&N Air and oil filters
Crawford Gymkhana exhaust
Brembo GT brakes, 6 pot fronts and 4 pot rears
Tein suspension
Work Emotion wheels
Falken tires
Driveshaft Shop turbo axels / CV joints
EcuTek RaceROM  tune by Crawford

comments.author: hudson fox

comments.text:
+3.8drew I like the new mustang too. But id prefer the smaller engine with 
the eco boost lol and i know a lot of people were dismissing that version 
because it didnt have a big engine. I do wish they had done more tuning 
with the trd version, but they basically only upgraded its aerodynamics by 
a bit, at the very least subaru is coming out with a STI version that will 
use their new EJ20 engine. At this point its no use trading up for me im 
already invested in upgrading and tuning my engine. I agree interior isnt 
as important when youre in a drivers car, just as long as the seats and 
positioning are comfortable.
comments.author: hudson fox

comments.text:
These cars just dont make power for cheep which is sad because they could 
be really good cars but i guess Toyota doesn't want any fast cars anymore. 
As for the v6 mustang thats one of the best cars you can buy brand new for 
cheep. They have soo many aftermarket mods that can be done to them. The 
3.7l cyclone engine can hold 500hp on the stock internals and still get 
high 20's for mpg. I never understood why people care about the interior of 
a car since they should be focusing on driving and not how an interior 
looks, i understand if the interior is completely destroyed thats when it 
would matter. Please name a better new car for 22k that offers as much as 
the mustang does.
comments.author: 3.8drew

comments.text:
+LegendInThaMakin it isnt supposed to be a powerfull car, its on the same 
level as the mx 5 miata and driveability, its no drag car but it has the

to take stock brz/frs with no sweat, that guy you raced was an idiot for 
thinking he can take a any bmw especially one thats modded or tuned in a 
drag race  where power is what matters most.
comments.author: hudson fox

comments.text:
+hudson fox I want to love this car, I really do... but it just fucking 
sucks. Looks great but I reaaaally lacks power.

I own a 09 bmw 335i, plenty mods on it.. I drove my friends brz.. god this 
car is so fucking weak. its such a shame cus it looks so good.. even when 
my 335i was stock I could destroy this thing... it does 0-60 in what? 6 
seconds? v6 Accords and civic si's could eat this thing alive.

I just remember stepping out of this car feeling so disgusted.. my friend 
loves it tho, she's a girl so I guess it suits her.

Yesterday this dude in a frs that looks just like this one wanted to race 
me. I told him id only race for $100, he said deal. I ate him alive.. used 
60 bucks to fill my tank, spent 20 on dinner for me and my brother, and 
paid my sister the remaining 20 I owed her from last week.

Brz sucks :/
comments.author: LegendInThaMakin

comments.text:

comments.author: Smithy

comments.text:
Could I also point out that I've driven a mustang before, and the build 
quality is just subpar? Drive it above 100mp/h and you can hear weird 
sounds everywhere in the car, like something's about to break all the time. 
It also can't corner to save your life. Keep that in mind when you're 
talking about a 300hp car with 22k. The engineering put into the build 
quality and finetuning geometrical values to make a car perform good, cost 
money. Has anyone seen the mustang's breaks? Suspension? Aerodynamics? Yes, 
they all suck, which cuts down the price quite a lot. Plus, the gt86 is 
made to be tuned, that has been the Japanese style for decades. It has a 
solid foundation of quality body materials, low center of gravity, tight 
chassis, etc. People need to realize there's so much more engineering to be 
done than just throwing in a big V8 (that isn't even high tech by today's 
standards anyway) and running into straight lines in the desert. Research 
please.
comments.author: SaladFingers

comments.text:
+MrGencyExit64 i personally see muscle cars as nice sound and lots of 
horsepower and especially torque. but 20 hp isnt worth loosing so much of 
the nice handling. im pretty sure the GT86 (or BRZ if you wish) handles 
better than a mustang.

comments.text:
I would also really like to clear the air with the BRZ/FRS rumors of this 
turbo kit not working correctly or having problems....

There are No problems associated with the Crawford turbo kit. 

No doubt, the BRZ above had a hesitation at times, threw out the video. You 
just can't deny it!!
With that being said!!! This is a test drive...on tunned ..where the whole 
purpose is too push the limits of a factory vehicle. 
And because this boxer motor is more than doubling its original power, well 
its going to need a break, after ragging it out. ANY motor that has an 
unbelievable amount of power added will over heat if your attacking the 
track. Hope this helps! 



﻿
comments.author: Alexander Guzak

comments.text:
I'm going to go ahead and confirm that Quirt Crawford is the king! Hands 
down! I was very lucky to ride with Quirt in the Crawford BRZ the other day 
and I can honestly say I've never been so impressed with a frs/BRZ, his 
driving!!, and the company Crawford..... These guys are at the top of their 
game and have definitely set the bar. Quirts history with tunning cars goes 
wayy back, and it really shows when you get behind the wheel of a car he's 
tuned. If you want a very reliable, powerful car with the the best ( in my 
opinion) tunning available....Crawford ...Crawford....CRAWFORD!!!

The Crawford BRZ left me Breathless.... But still remains a very drivable 
daily driver. Don't be fooled by the videos, go for a test drive with Quirt 
and you'll see disposable power is not a bad thing, especially with the 
amazing traction control systems on these BRZ/FRS!

Thank you Quirt for all the time you've spent running countless dyno runs 
to perfect this FRS/BRZ!! 
﻿
comments.author: Alexander Guzak

comments.text: Thank you sir.

comments.text: Can you send it in Europe? Do you have some authorized partner?

comments.text:

changed over the years is the tuning. We are currently in the process of

comments.author: Keller60Music

comments.text:
The 450 HP Crawford Performance Turbo BRZ - /TUNED: 
http://youtu.be/oLP-HCcX9as﻿
comments.author: Paulo Souza

comments.text:
Noob tuner question, but aside from the turbo itself, where are the other 
horsepower gains coming from on this build? If the FR-S/BRZ has 200HP from 
the factory, and this car has double that, where's the other 50HP coming 
from?

I'm curious because I drive a turbo FR-S and the car is great. The tune is 
solid and I no longer have the 4k RPM power plateau like the BRZ in this 
video, but I still get the feeling like the car could use another another 
50-100HP.

When I'm driving in colder climates, the car feels perfect and I'm 
satisfied with its power. But I live in Florida, so the only time the car 
feels responsive is when there's a cold front or when I travel out of state.

If the stock engine has more potential than an EJ motor, how can I get more 
out of it like Crawford did with this BRZ? Outside of an engine swap, 
bigger turbo, or E85, what options are there to get more power?﻿
comments.author: Jigglypoof

comments.text:
The turbo is what makes the power. As an example, for every pound of boost 
you will get 10 to 15HP depending on how efficient your system is. Our 
turbo BRZ makes 430HP on 91 octane fuel and 500HP on E85 with peak power at 
8,100 RPM
